message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Repaglinide is a sulfonylurea agent, similar to Glyburide, which also stimulates insulin release from pancreatic beta cells. Linagliptin and Miglitol have different mechanisms of action, while Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that increases insulin sensitivity in peripheral tissues.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Repaglinide is a meglitinide, which stimulates the release of insulin from the pancreas. Glyburide is also a sulfonylurea drug that works in a similar way to stimulate insulin release from the pancreas. The other options (linagliptin, pioglitazone, miglitol) have different mechanisms of action in treating diabetes mellitus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Repaglinide, like Glyburide, is a sulfonylurea medication that works by stimulating insulin secretion from pancreatic beta cells. Linagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor, pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione, and miglitol is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor, which all have different mechanisms of action for managing diabetes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Repaglinide is a sulfonylurea drug, which stimulates insulin secretion by binding to a specific receptor on β-cells in the pancreas. Glyburide also belongs to the same class of drugs, hence it has the most similar mechanism of action. Linagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor, pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione and miglitol is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor, which have different mechanisms of action.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Repaglinide and Glyburide both belong to the class of drugs known as sulfonylureas, which work by stimulating insulin release from beta cells in the pancreas. Linagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor, Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione (TZD) which increases insulin sensitivity, and Miglitol is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor which delays the absorption of carbohydrates.

Linagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor, Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione, and Miglitol is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor, all of which have different mechanisms of action.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Repaglinide is a meglitinide, which stimulates insulin secretion from pancreatic beta cells. Glyburide is also a sulfonylurea that works in a similar way by stimulating insulin secretion. Linagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor, pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione, and miglitol is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor, all of which work through different mechanisms. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) Glyburide.

Glyburide is also a sulfonylurea and works similarly. Linagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor, pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione, and miglitol is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor, all of which work by different mechanisms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Repaglinide works by stimulating insulin secretion from the pancreas, similarly to glyburide. Linagliptin works by inhibiting an enzyme that breaks down incretin hormones, while pioglitazone improves insulin sensitivity and miglitol slows down the breakdown of carbohydrates.
